entry.title: æ€ç»´å¯è¿ª
entry.content:
Think about these quotes through frequent retrospections.

Iã€Think big enough, donâ€™t get stuck by the small stuff.

People are often unreasonable, illogical and self-centered. Forgive them anyway.
If you are kind, people may accuse you of selfish ulterior motives. Be kind anyway.
If you are successful, you will win some false friends and some true enemies. Succeed anyway. ~~
~~If you are honest and frank, people may cheat you. Be honest and frank anyway.
What you spend years building, someone could destroy overnight. Build anyway.
If you find serenity and happiness, they maybe jealous. Be happy anyway.
The good you do today, people will often forget tomorrow. Do good anyway.
Give the world the best you have, and it may never be enough. Give the best youâ€™ve got anyway.
You see, in the final analysis it is between you and God. It was never between you and them anyway.

IIã€Simple, yet powerful statements.

â€œYou donâ€™t have a lot of envy.â€
â€œYou donâ€™t have a lot of resentment.â€
â€œYou donâ€™t overspend your income.â€
â€œYou stay cheerful in spite of your troubles.â€
â€œYou deal with reliable people.â€
â€œAnd you do what youâ€™re supposed to do.â€

IIIã€26 signsâ€¦?

  1. You realise that most of the bad behaviour of other people really comes down to fear and anxiety â€“ rather than, as it is generally easier to presume, nastiness or idiocy. You loosen your hold on self-righteousness and stop thinking of the world as populated by either monsters or fools. It makes things less black and white at first, but in time, a great deal more interesting.

  2. You learn that what is in your head canâ€™t automatically be understood by other people. You realise that, unfortunately, you will have to articulate your intentions and feelings with the use of words â€“ and canâ€™t fairly blame others for not getting what you mean until youâ€™ve spoken calmly and clearly.

  3. You learn that â€“ remarkably â€“ you do sometimes get things wrong. With huge courage, you take your first faltering steps towards (once in a while) apologising.

  4. You learn to be confident not by realising that youâ€™re great, but by learning that everyone else is just as stupid, scared and lost as you are. Weâ€™re all making it up as we go along, and thatâ€™s fine.

  5. You stop suffering from impostor syndrome because you can accept that there is no such thing as a legitimate anyone. We are all, to varying degrees, attempting to act a role while keeping our follies and wayward sides at bay.

  6. You forgive your parents because you realise that they didnâ€™t put you on this earth in order to insult you. They were just painfully out of their depth and struggling with demons of their own. Anger turns, at points, to pity and compassion.

  7. You learn the enormous influence of so-called â€˜smallâ€™ things on mood: bed-times, blood sugar and alcohol levels, degrees of background stress etc. And as a result, you learn never to bring up an important, contentious issue with a loved one until everyone is well rested, no one is drunk, youâ€™ve had some food, nothing else is alarming you and you arenâ€™t rushing to catch a train.

  8. You realise that when people close to you nag you, or are unpleasant or vindictive, they usually arenâ€™t just trying to wind you up, they may be trying to get your attention in the only way they know how. You learn to detect the desperation beneath your loved oneâ€™s less impressive moments â€“ and, on a good day, you interpret them with love rather than judge them.

  9. You give up sulking. If someone hurts you, you donâ€™t store up the hatred and the hurt for days. You remember youâ€™ll be dead soon. You donâ€™t expect others to know whatâ€™s wrong. You tell them straight and if they get it, you forgive them. And if they donâ€™t, in a different way, you forgive them too.

  10. You realise that because life is so very short, itâ€™s extremely important that you to try to say what you really mean, focus on what you really want, and tell those you care about that they matter immensely to you. Probably every day.

  11. ~~You cease to believe in perfection in pretty much every area. There arenâ€™t any perfect people, perfect jobs or perfect lives. Instead, you pivot towards an appreciation of what is (to use the psychoanalyst Donald Winnicottâ€™s exemplary phrase) â€˜good enough.â€™ You realise that many things in your life are at once quite frustrating â€“ and yet, in many ways, eminently good enough. ~~

  12. You learn the virtues of being a little more pessimistic about how things will turn out â€“ and as a result, emerge as a calmer, more patient and more forgiving soul. You lose some of your idealism and become a far less maddening person (less impatient, less rigid, less angry).

  13. You learn to see that everyoneâ€™s weaknesses of character are linked to counter-balancing strengths. Rather than isolating their weaknesses, you look at the whole picture: yes, someone is rather pedantic, but theyâ€™re also beautifully precise and a rock at times of turmoil. Yes someone is a bit messy, but at the same time brilliantly creative and very visionary. You realise (truly) that perfect people donâ€™t exist â€“ and that every strength will be tagged with a weakness.

  14. You learn the virtues of compromise. You learn to settle in certain areas â€“ and recognise that youâ€™re being mature rather than weak when you do so. You might stay together with someone primarily for the children, or because youâ€™re afraid of being alone. You might put up with some inconveniences because you know that a friction-free life is a mirage.

  15. You fall in love a bit less easily. Itâ€™s difficult, in a way. When you were less mature, you could develop a crush in an instant. Now, youâ€™re poignantly aware that everyone, however externally charming or accomplished, would be a bit of a pain from close up. You develop loyalty to what you already have.

  16. You learn that you are â€“ rather surprisingly â€“ quite a difficult person to live with. You shed some of your earlier sentimentality towards yourself. You go into friendships and relationships offering others kindly warnings of how and when you might prove a challenge.

  17. You learn to forgive yourself for your errors and foolishness. You realise the unfruitful self-absorption involved in simply flogging yourself for past misdeeds. You become more of a friend to yourself. Of course youâ€™re an idiot, but youâ€™re still a loveable one, as we all are.

  18. You learn that part of what maturity involves is making peace with the stubbornly child-like bits of you that will always remain. You cease trying to be a grown up at every occasion. You accept that we all have our regressive moments â€“ and when the inner two year old you rears its head, you greet them generously and give them the attention they need.

  19. You cease to put too much hope in grand plans for the kind of happiness you expect can last for years. You celebrate the little things that go well. You realise that satisfaction comes in increments of minutes. Youâ€™re delighted if one day passes by without too much bother. You take a greater interest in flowers and in the evening sky. You develop a taste for small pleasures.

  20. What people in general think of you ceases to be such a concern. You realise the minds of others are muddled places and you donâ€™t try so hard to polish your image in everyone elseâ€™s eyes. What counts is that you and one or two others are OK with you being you. You give up on fame and start to rely on love.

  21. You get better at hearing feedback. Rather than assuming that anyone who criticises you is either trying to humiliate you or is making a mistake, you accept that maybe it would be an idea to take a few things on board. You start to see that you can listen to a criticism and survive it â€“ without having to put on your armour and deny there was ever a problem.

  22. You realise the extent to which you tend to live, day by day, in too great a proximity to certain of your problems and issues. You remember â€“ more and more â€“ that you need to get perspective on things that pain you. You take more walks in nature, you might get a pet (they donâ€™t fret like we do) and you appreciate the distant galaxies above us in the night sky.

  23. You cease to be so easily triggered by peopleâ€™s negative behaviour. Before getting furious or riled or upset, you pause to wonder what they might really have meant. You realise that there may be a disjuncture between what someone said and what you immediately assumed they meant.

  24. You recognise how your distinctive past colours your response to events â€“ and learn to compensate for the distortions that result. You accept that, because of how your childhood went, you have a predisposition to exaggerate in certain areas. You become suspicious of your own first impulses around particular topics. You realise â€“ sometimes â€“ not to go with your feelings.

  25. When you start a friendship, you realise that other people donâ€™t principally want to know your good news, so much as gain an insight into what troubles and worries you, so that they can in turn feel less lonely with the pains of their own hearts. You become a better friend because you see that what friendship is really about is a sharing of vulnerability.

  26. You learn to calm your anxieties not by telling yourself that everything will be fine. In many areas, it wonâ€™t. You build up a capacity to think that even where things go wrong, they are broadly survivable. You realise that there is always a plan B; that the world is broad, that a few kindly souls are always to be found and that the most horrid things are, in the end, endurable.
entry.summary: Think about these quotes through frequent retrospections.

entry.title: Self-Check Card ğŸ§· Systems Design
entry.content:
Master the basic systems design principles, they are really helpful in your day-to-day work.

â€¦â€¦

Part I, General System Design

No.Quiz
1Design Pastebin.com (or Bit.ly)
2Design the Twitter timeline and search (or Facebook feed and search)
3Design a web crawler
4Design Mint.com
5Design the data structures for a social network
6Design a key-value store for a search engine
7Design Amazonâ€™s sales ranking by category feature
8Design a system that scales to millions of users on AWS

Part II, Machine Learning Related Systems

No.Quiz
1-
entry.summary: Master the basic systems design principles, they are really helpful in your day-to-day work.

entry.title: Self-Check Card ğŸ§· Algorithms
entry.content:
Master all the basic algorithms, they will help you to write better programs.

No.Quiz
69Sqrt(x)
146LRU Cache
158Read N Characters Given Read4 II - Call multiple times
168Excel Sheet Column Title
209Minimum Size Subarray Sum
260Single Number III
285Inorder Successor in BST
300Longest Increasing Subsequence
310Minimum Height Trees
319Bulb Switcher
341Flatten Nested List Iterator
376Wiggle Subsequence
382Linked List Random Node
409Longest Palindrome
413Arithmetic Slices
424Longest Repeating Character Replacement
426Convert Binary Search Tree to Sorted Doubly Linked List
4544Sum II
492Construct the Rectangle
496Next Greater Element I
497Random Point in Non-overlapping Rectangles
498Diagonal Traverse
507Perfect Number
516Longest Palindromic Subsequence
518Coin Change 2
524Longest Word in Dictionary through Deleting
525Contiguous Array
540Single Element in a Sorted Array
545Boundary of Binary Tree
604Design Compressed String Iterator
622Design Circular Queue
628Maximum Product of Three Numbers
663Equal Tree Partition
731My Calendar II
738Monotone Increasing Digits
754Reach a Number
794Valid Tic-Tac-Toe State
827Making A Large Island
834Sum of Distances in Tree
852Peak Index in a Mountain Array
856Score of Parentheses
877Stone Game
901Online Stock Span
914X of a Kind in a Deck of Cards
915Partition Array into Disjoint Intervals
926Flip String to Monotone Increasing
947Most Stones Removed with Same Row or Column
971Flip Binary Tree To Match Preorder Traversal
1013Partition Array Into Three Parts With Equal Sum
1018Binary Prefix Divisible By 5
1059All Paths from Source Lead to Destination
1080Insufficient Nodes in Root to Leaf Paths
1089Duplicate Zeros
1171Remove Zero Sum Consecutive Nodes from Linked List
1206Design Skiplist
1209Remove All Adjacent Duplicates in String II
1310XOR Queries of a Subarray
1316Distinct Echo Substrings
1361Validate Binary Tree Nodes
1372Longest ZigZag Path in a Binary Tree
1395Count Number of Teams
1519Number of Nodes in the Sub-Tree With the Same Label
1560Most Visited Sector in a Circular Track
1561Maximum Number of Coins You Can Get
1566Detect Pattern of Length M Repeated K or More Times
1586Binary Search Tree Iterator II
1602Find Nearest Right Node in Binary Tree
1605Find Valid Matrix Given Row and Column Sums
1608Special Array With X Elements Greater Than or Equal X
1612Check If Two Expression Trees are Equivalent
1631Path With Minimum Effort
1638Count Substrings That Differ by One Character
1639Number of Ways to Form a Target String Given a Dictionary
1642Furthest Building You Can Reach
1660Correct a Binary Tree
1664Ways to Make a Fair Array
1701Average Waiting Time
1758Minimum Changes To Make Alternating Binary String
1769Minimum Number of Operations to Move All Balls to Each Box
1792Maximum Average Pass Ratio
1805Number of Different Integers in a String
1806Minimum Number of Operations to Reinitialize a Permutation
1823Find the Winner of the Circular Game
1834Single-Threaded CPU
1839Longest Substring Of All Vowels in Order
1876Substrings of Size Three with Distinct Characters
1902Depth of BST Given Insertion Order
1909Remove One Element to Make the Array Strictly Increasing
1944Number of Visible People in a Queue
1966Binary Searchable Numbers in an Unsorted Array
entry.summary: Master all the basic algorithms, they will help you to write better programs.
